Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: The photocatalysts were prepared by a sol-gel hydrothermal synthesis (see Scheme S1).All of the reagents were analytical grade and used without further purification.In a typical synthesis, 5 mmol of In(NO 3 ) 3 4.5H 2 O was mixed with 30 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) (99,Wako Co., Japan).After stirring for 10 min, 20 mL of isopropanol (Wako, 99) was dropped into the solution and then the solution was heated it at 80 C until totally volatilized to obtain a white gel.After milling the gel completely, the

irradiation were carried out respectively to confirm that the CH 4 was obtained from photocatalytic reaction indeed.There was no O 2 evolution detected in the CO 2 photoreduction processes, which is similar with previous reports 262728.According to these previous reports, the produced O 2 was suggested to be consumed in several processes, such as chemical or physical adsorptions on the surface of photocatalysts.Furthermore, some other kinds of hydrocarbons and organics were obtained, such as aldehyde,

theory demonstrated that the potentials of valence band and conduction band of In(OH) 3 are both suitable for CO 2 photoreduction.The photocatalytic efficiencies of the samples were characterized by testing the photoreduction of CO 2 to CH 4 under full-arc Xe lamp irradiation.The sample modified with mesoporous structure is about 20 times higher in efficiency than that of sample without mesoporous structure, which is attributed to the outstanding structure characteristics in higher surface area and strong

model was performed to determine the most stable structure.Then its electronic structure was calculated using a standard Cambridge serial total energy package (CASTEP) code 3,4.The electron-core interaction was represented via ultrasoft pseudopotentials with a plane-wave basis cutoff energy of 340 eV.The electronic exchangecorrelation energy was treated within the frame-work of the local density approximation (LDA).The self-consistent field (SCF) tolerance was all 1 10 -6 eVatom. A 300 W Xe arc lamp was

Cu-K radiation ( 1.54178A).Scanning electron microscopy images and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy patterns were recorded with a JEOL 6700F field emission scanning electron microscopy.Transmission electron microscopy and high-resolution were performed with a JEOL 2100F field emission transmission electron microscopy operated at 200 kV.The pulsed adsorption of CO 2 was recorded with a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2930 chemisorption analyzer.Here the powder samples were pretreated at 150 C in Ar for 1 h

The photocatalysts were prepared by a sol-gel hydrothermal synthesis (see Scheme S1).All of the reagents were analytical grade and used without further purification.In a typical synthesis, 5 mmol of In(NO 3 ) 3 4.5H 2 O was mixed with 30 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) (99,Wako Co., Japan).After stirring for 10 min, 20 mL of isopropanol (Wako, 99) was dropped into the solution and then the solution was heated it at 80 C until totally volatilized to obtain a white gel.After milling the gel completely, the
